unnormalised: The local sabzi mandi witnessed a price surge today, impacting household budgets across the city. Tomato prices have skyrocketed to ₹80/kg, a steep climb from ₹40/kg just last week, according to vendors. Onion prices also saw a hike, reaching ₹35 per kg.
normalised: The local sabzi mandi witnessed a price surge today, impacting household budgets across the city. Tomato prices have skyrocketed to rupee eighty per kilogram, a steep climb from rupee forty per kilogram just last week, according to vendors. Onion prices also saw a hike, reaching rupee thirty five per kilogram.

unnormalised: “Barish ki wajah se fasal kharab ho gaya,” explained Ramlal, a vegetable vendor from the mandi, meaning the crops got ruined because of rain. "Gaon se supply kam ho gaya hai." He added that the supply from the villages has decreased.

unnormalised: Customers are feeling the pinch. "I usually buy 2 kgs of tomatoes," said Mrs. Sharma, a homemaker. "But now, I can only afford 1 kg. My budget is completely messed up." Coriander, a staple in Indian cooking, is now selling at a staggering ₹20 per bunch.

unnormalised: Potatoes, usually a budget-friendly option, have also experienced a price increase, now selling for ₹25/kg. Ladyfingers also saw a jump of ₹10 and are selling at ₹50/kg. The increased prices are affecting lower income group people drastically, and are forcing them to cut back on veggies in general.

unnormalised: Even grocery items like pulses and oil have seen a slight increase. 1 litre of sunflower oil now costs ₹160, up from ₹150 last month. Moong dal is selling at ₹110/kg, a rise of ₹5 from its previous price. These price increases are causing major issues in home budgets.

unnormalised: Shopkeepers are hoping for the prices to come back down by the end of the week if there is more supply. This issue has been seen frequently in the past and solutions like proper storage facilities are not being worked upon, which is a huge matter of concern for the government.
